issues.title: Unhandled Exception
issues.body:
Hello!

I've built slowmoVideo from source on Ubuntu 17.10. When I run File -> Render preview the program crashes and all the windows close (before I can read the debug window output). Output in the terminal is
```
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'QUnhandledException'
  what():  std::exception
Aborted (core dumped)
```
Anybody else getting a similar problem? Any tips to look into it further?

Thanks!

I compiled the binary from source and it starts up fine. But whenever I try to "open" a file I get the following errors and the program just hangs.

```
(slowmoUI:28283): GLib-GObject-WARNING **: cannot register existing type 'GdkWindow'

(slowmoUI:28283): GLib-CRITICAL **: g_once_init_leave: assertion 'result != 0' failed

(slowmoUI:28283): Gdk-CRITICAL **: gdk_window_ensure_native: assertion 'GDK_IS_WINDOW (window)' failed
```

After it hangs, I stopped it via SIGINT and got the following backtrace from gdb:

I installed all the dependencies listed on https://github.com/slowmoVideo/slowmoVideo/wiki/Download , but the "Qt5" part is not very verbose. Is there some dependency I am missing?

issues.title: Fedora 25-26  requirements
issues.body:
Hi,
In that page: http://slowmovideo.granjow.net/download.php
Fedora dnf command should install qt5-devel instead of qt4-devel. With QT4, slowmoUI crashes even if it compiles.

Thanks a lot.

commits.message:
Add STATIC to not list libB3D as dynamic library

Without that fix, we couldn't build a working RPM on Fedora. libV3D.so was listed to be required.

issues.title: slowmoUI doesnt update working project file when Save As
issues.body:
On Windows 10.
Have a project named "Project1.sVproj".
Make some changes, but don't want to overwrite old project so Save As "Project2.sVproj". 
Save is successful, but the current project remains the Project1.sVproj file, instead of switching to Project2.
Therefore any future Save (not SaveAs) would still mistakenly overwrite Project1, instead of amending Project2.

Seems like an easy fix.

Good work guys.

issues.title: Incorrect slowmoRenderer command leads to rm -rf to related directories
issues.body:
# What
I was figuring out how to utilize multiple CPU cores so I would like to experiment with the command line and perhaps apply GNU parallel. 

However during the experiment my home is completely wiped out due to incorrect usage on `slowmoRenderer`. 

Luckily I have hourly btrfs snapshot so restoring takes only few minutes without panic, no damage has been done except Dropbox client is confused. 

# Environment
- Arch Linux x86-64
- slowmovideo-git 20170312-1 (Latest git commit ATM)
- ffmpeg 1:3.3.2-1
- glew 2.0.0-1
- opencv 3.2.0-4
- qt5-script 5.9.0-1
- xdg-utils 1.1.2-1
- desktop-file-utils 0.23-1
- cmake 3.8.2-1
- gcc 7.1.1-2
- gcc-libs 7.1.1-2
- lib32-gcc-libs 7.1.1-3

# Steps to reproduce
1. Backup your important files or test in VM
2. `$ mkdir /tmp/out/ /tmp/project/ && touch /tmp/out/dontdeleteme /tmp/project/plsdontdeleteme`
3. Prepare a video file /tmp/video.mp4
4. Use slowmo UI to create a project file with that video, add some nodes, save the project file as `/tmp/project/bug.sVproj`
5. Use the incorrect command `$ slowmoRenderer /tmp/project/bug.sVproj -target /tmp/out/output.mp4`
6. You can see `/tmp/out/` and `/tmp/project/` are empty now.

issues.title: 60fps videos do not render in 60fps
issues.body:
As in, they do (output file is also 60fps) -- but they appear to running at half speed.

Input file: [out.zip](https://github.com/slowmoVideo/slowmoVideo/files/711360/out.zip)

Setup: Linear (1x) line from start to end of video (![screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11349175/22025063/2b8d7eb2-dcc4-11e6-90cf-ae829b488180.png))

Render Settings:
     - 60 frames per second
     - Size: small    - Interpolation: Forward interpolation (fast)
     - Optical Flow: OpenCV - Farneback  [Levels, WinSize, PolyS, Pyr, PolyN] ->  [3, 15, 1.2, 0.5, 5]
     - Motion blur: convolution, max samples: 64,  samples for slowmo: 16


Edit: 
 I tried setting the Project Preference FPS value to 60/1 instead of 24/1, it made no difference to the output render.

Edit2:
 A 1 minute 60fps source video renders to 2:40 at 60fps, so it doesn't look like any frames are actually dropped.

`ffmpeg -i rendered.mp4 -vf "setpts=$(echo  'scale=2;   25 / 60' | bc)*PTS"  correct.mp4` seems to be a quick fix for now. 

Doing this filter straight from the rendered/rendered-%05d.png folder also works but above is just as good

issues.title: Ignore identic frames
issues.body:
Some programs (eg. Movie Maker) can't deal with the optical flow so when you slow a video down, instead of computing the missing frames they just repeat one frame many times. It would be awesome if Slomo Video recognized those identic frames and acted as if they weren't there at all. This would mean I could edit the speed of the video in Movie Maker (it has simple preview, supports music etc.) and then let Slomo Video do the work.

Nevertheless you've done a great job! What a fantastic program!

issues.title: Impossible to add a doc package with the current CMake files
issues.body:
Trying to add a new slowmovideo-doc package will end up in Debian / Ubuntu with a `CMake` install which will not move / install the binaries at `usr/bin` and the desktop launcher at `usr/share/applications`, as the bin and applications directories are build empty.
The files stay in the debian `temp` directory.
Obviously `CMake files` were conceived to build only one package.

Both are properly installed otherwise it won't compile. We have a problem at link time, meaning some compilation options are missing.

Well as I was about to close I found this link which is closer to our problem and bolster my own impression.

https://github.com/tum-vision/lsd_slam/issues/29

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23585435/cannot-call-xinitthreads

`"undefined reference to symbol"` is a linker error, not a compiler error. If you get this message, the compiler has already finished compiled the file into an object file, but is unable to find the shared library which contains the function to link the object file into an executable.

Using gcc, it generally means you have to add some -l flags, like so:

`gcc prog.c -lX11`

`You can try adding it in the CMakesList.txt that references live_slam:
https://github.com/tum-vision/lsd_slam/blob/master/lsd_slam_core/CMakeLists.txt`

One participant acknowledges that adding the X11 library to the compilation command line as `-lX11` solves the issue.

Good morning. I believe you shouldn’t see an -lX11 on the "Linking CXX executable slowmoFlowBuilder" which is where the error pops up and the part of my log I did publish above, at least if the source flowBuilder.cpp was not build against the X11 library.

However to correct this error I would expect to see a -lX11 on the compile command line for the flowBuilder.cpp source. For this to happen I think X11 should appear at least once in src/CMakeLists.txt and that's not yet the case ?

The project I mentioned in my previous post had to add X11 in  CMakeLists.txt in these lines:

`# build shared library.
rosbuild_add_library(lsdslam SHARED ${SOURCE_FILES})
target_link_libraries(lsdslam ${FABMAP_LIB} g2o_core g2o_stuff csparse cxsparse g2o_solver_csparse g2o_csparse_extension g2o_types_sim3 g2o_types_sba X11)
rosbuild_link_boost(lsdslam thread)
`

`

To get flowBuilder.cpp.o properly build we would need to have -I/usr/include/X11 and that's not the case.

This time it looks like I need to have my account authorized by an admin of the repository ?
I need a write access ...

Can someone help me ?

I have already made a new branch in my own clone repo. as detailed above.

However, AFAIK the create pull request page on this project can only see branches in the GitHub repo. Since my branch is not pushed, I can't create any pull request here.

https://github.com/slowmoVideo/slowmoVideo/compare

That's it. What is your way of living here ? Only you are allowed to create branches and then pull requests on GitHub ? There are other more open projects on GitHub I believe.

@valgit Just a simple reminder to the owner of this repository:

A basic rule of thumb is that when you have more than 1 user (here you have 3 users on two different platforms) complaining about the very same deficiency, then there is a 100 % chance that your code is deficient.

I have devised a working patch which corrects the afore mentioned deficiencies. slowmoVideo compiles fine and creates packages on my system now. However, since the owner of the repo (@valgit) is denying me a write acces to this GitHub repository, therefore preventing me to create a new branch and create right after a pull request, I will keep this to myself only.

If I understand clearly his own postings, everything is right in his published code and complainers are plain idiots.

So long :-)

OK. I loosed my nerve in the early process. That was my first pull request on GitHub. I didn't know much of all the process. Now the pull request is effective and any one here can review and test it. I believe its modifications are minimal on the original source.

I've seen I don't need a write access to the original repository. So forget about it.

Your point of understanding why you can build (and may be other) is valid. However the most urgent need is to understand why other people cannot build in the first place. in addition, I will need to see your system to fully understand your particular configuration. On some sources, you can build from cmake, from qmake or use command lines instead of Debian helpers ... Building is not a one way street.

I use only standard Debian helpers in fully provisioned debian folders.

This update of src/CMakeLists.txt should solve debian and RPM builds as well (@lherbolt was using Fedora 22), as long as they use a build process using only cmake without any other command line parameters.

For those on Debian / Ubuntu systems I have a Launchpad repository with up to date Photo (and some Video) Applications for all Ubuntu supported releases. They are build against the latest versions of libraries (they are part of the repo):

https://launchpad.net/~anton+/+archive/ubuntu/kde-photo-apps
https://launchpad.net/~anton+/+archive/ubuntu/photo-video-apps

And some various particular or system related applications

https://launchpad.net/~anton+/+archive/ubuntu/miscellaneous

I was trying to build slowmoVideo for the photo-video-apps Launchpad repo.

I think you may suffer from the same deficiency I had some days ago. See Issue `Undefined reference to symbol 'XCreateWindow'`

The file src/CMakeLists.txt was not listing `X11` as part of the set of the `target_link_libraries` . Therefore shared libraries (of the project) were not build against the `X11 library`.

I pushed a pull request today which was accepted and merged in the project. Which seems to close this issue.

Would you like to test the newly merged repository ? and tell us if it solves your problem ?

@forresthopkinsa Interesting comment about access right of project folders. I didn't test anything yet. Can you details some of the action you made to witness this ?

If you confirm the problem, can you open an issue here ?

No Launchpad does not build a package solely from source. You need to provide a debian folder in order to proceed. The current debian folder of slowmoVideo is broken.

In a few days (as some issues with the source code are solved) I plan to add slowmoVideo in my Ubuntu Launchpad PPA for Photo (and some Video) Applications for all Ubuntu supported releases:

https://launchpad.net/%7Eanton+/+archive/ubuntu/photo-video-apps

I am using Ubuntu Trusty 14.04. Since Trusty both Qt4 and Qt5 are part of the system. 

By default OpenCV CMakeLists.txt file set QT support as OFF:
`OCV_OPTION(WITH_QT             "Build with Qt Backend support"               OFF  IF (NOT ANDROID AND NOT IOS) )`

There is no Qt4 or Qt5 specific switch. If you set this switch to ON then it will check first for the availability of Qt5 then Qt4, if none is found you end up with an error.

By default the opencv build by Debian / Ubuntu does not support Qt. So better to stay the course.

When building `slowmoVideo` you have a `cmake` switch as well, allowing you to force the use of Qt4 if Qt5 is detected on your system (by default if Qt5 is found, `slowmoVideo` will build wth Qt5).

I use the `cmake` option `-DFORCE_QT4=ON` to build on Qt4.

So don't see your point of modifying the project source. To me it's working fine.
Looking at other issues it looks like the `Gentoo build Failure` issue `#53` arises from the same missing `X11 library` in the set of `target_link_libraries` .

Well, I believe its only your business to see how you configure the build of other packages in your system. Here OpenCV.

However, as I said before I don't see the need to build OpenCV with Qt support. OpenCV is a low level library and is ill fit to manage end user Qt applications. As a reference I gave you above, none of the distributions I know of (Debian and Ubuntu) does build OpenCV with Qt Support.

OK. In Debian / Ubuntu the file `gpumat.hpp` you mentioned as missing on your system is part of either package `libopencv-core-dev` or package `libopencv-gpu-dev`.

See http://packages.ubuntu.com/search?searchon=contents&keywords=gpumat.hpp&mode=exactfilename&suite=trusty&arch=any

May be consider adding a dependence in your build or make sure you have this installed / build appropriately. These packages are part of `opencv`. As well you may consider to build `opencv` from the latest source and make sure you are not missing anything. In Gentoo I know there is no packages and everything is compiled and build locally.

Anyway all includes files are part of the source itself. I have opencv 2.4.9 in my Ubuntu system and `gpumat.hpp` appears twice in the source:

`opencv-2.4.9+dfsg/modules/core/include/opencv2/core`
`opencv-2.4.9+dfsg/modules/gpu/include/opencv2/gpu`

To check on the availability of required resources to build from a source is not the business of the source itself e.g. in Debian / Ubuntu it is dealt with the debian/ folder which should check that all required packages containing the required resources are installed properly.

Missing header / include files which are part of a third party source only means you failed to installed required resources on your system.

issues.title: Make a core library reusable in other projects
issues.body:
Hi,

I just wanted to report that the code from slowmoVideo has been used in this GStreamer plugin:
https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=708545

AFAICS the author (not me) took the core files and stripped the Qt and ffmpeg bits to port the functionality to GStreamer.

This made me think that maybe slowmoVideo can provide the core functionality as a shared library which does not depend on Qt/ffmpeg for other projects to reuse without having to duplicate the code and diverge from the upstream.

However not knowing the slowmoVideo code, I don't know if this is feasible or if it would introduce too much overhead, so I am asking you.

Thanks,
   Antonio

issues.title: opencv can mix qt5/qt4
issues.body:
I have a system with both qt4 and qt5 installed, and I've spent the last hour pulling what remains of my hair out trying to figure out why the build wasn't working. Actually it works just fine. It builds without any problems and immediately segfaults when starting it up. Gdb revealed it was segfaulting in a qt4 library. Which was odd because I had checked and dug through every build file trying to figure out how the heck the executables were getting linked against the qt4 libraries.

Well, turns out that if opencv is built with qt4 support enabled, it pulls in the qt4 libraries with it, which sabotage the build. Rebuilding without qt4 support in opencv fixes everything.

So, is there perhaps a means to move libs pulled in by opencv to the back of the line so they don't make false positive symbol matches that are supposed to be provided by qt5?

issue_comments.body: It's not about modifying the source, it's about checking that opencv is using the same version of qt. The build system pulls in the libraries that opencv are linked to, including qt4/5. It doesn't matter if you configure cmake to use qt5 if opencv is using qt4. In that scenario it ends up linking qt5 code to qt4 libraries. That will successfully build since the API interfaces are similar, but of course will not run.

There is an issue with newer ffmpeg versions, 2.3.1 changed some part in the API that causes frame numbers to be wrong. Are you on one of this versions too?

I could ask you now if I should warn on my web site that morons should not try to use it. But I won't do it. Eventually you develop an immunity against the impolite part in mails like yours.
1. This has historical reasons which are not present anymore. Feel free to submit a patch fixing this.
2. Glad that the compiling guides are amazing. Btw the github doc refers to the web site. Glad too that they are different because otherwise readers would suffer of infinite recursion.
3. Sorry that I cannot keep up with all package changes in all existing distributions. cmake should usually give a good idea about missing packages. 

Regarding the library problems: ffmpeg and libav tend to change faster than one can adapt to it, usually resulting in the ffmpeg version you have available being exactly the wrong one because they changed a bit over there. If it does not work with -54 but only with -53, it is because ffmpeg is not, and has never been, backwards compatible. Maintaining compatibility is as much of a pain in the ass as reading your message might be for others.

I currently do not have time to maintain slowmoVideo, but there is a great guy called @valgit who added support for the newer libav/ffmpeg versions: https://github.com/valgit/slowmoVideo
Is maybe the CMake cache outdated? Does it work with a fresh build directory?
GPL. For me, LGPL is fine too. I will let @valgit decide.

If you right-click in a segment, you should be able to select the speedup factor (0.5 in your case). The start frame has to be placed on a full frame, otherwise every single (not every second) image will be interpolated. There is no feature for this though, but would be useful to move a node to the previous or next full input frame.
For the node, both input and output frame has to be an integer value. Then we map the input frame to the output frame exactly.

pull_requests.title: remove debian packaging from master
pull_requests.body:
Hello @valgit 

this is complemented by my other pull request. Hereby I'd recommend to remove the `debian/` folder from the master branch and maintain debian packaging on a separate tree. This allows to use the `git-buildpackage` tooling, which is very convenient.

according to Debian recommendation, "upstream" trees should not
provide a debian/ subdirectory. Rather, the debian package
can be maintained on a separate Git branch, which allows
tools like git-buildpackage to generate a complete Debian
package and release tarball with a single invocation.

Disclaimer: this was done in two days with no regard whatsoever for good engineering practices, as highlighted by such a file : https://github.com/MathieuDuponchelle/gst-plugins-base/blob/dba7c98072049c8dd3f8aee0d43cb10dee865e7d/gst/slowmo/QPoint_crack.h .

This mostly proves it can be done, my main goal there if I remember correcly was to get rid of the qt dependency and to use the C version of opencv, it introduces a gstreamer dependency instead though, which would have to be removed too to offer a library with the minimal amount of strings attached.

Please do ping me if you folks make progress with this someday, I wouldn't mind rewriting a cleaner plugin :)

Hey, you should look at the main entry point for the plugin at https://github.com/MathieuDuponchelle/gst-plugins-base/blob/slowmotion/gst/slowmo/gstslowmo.c . The bridge between gstreamer and slowmovideo is made there and also in https://github.com/MathieuDuponchelle/gst-plugins-base/blob/slowmotion/gst/slowmo/interpolator_sV.cpp .

Basically what I can think of would be:
- "Native" support for as many colorspaces as possible (ie without conversion)
- a callback based API (particularly critical if you want the library to be usable directly in a python GUI application for example)
- Ability to feed the libary one buffer / frame at a time, instead of having to keep a reference on the previous buffer.
- Making the "reuse flows" option configurable separately, instead of having to pass it at each "interpolate" call.

That's all I can think of for now by looking back at the code, please make this happen :D

Also if there's any way to make the code work "real-time", even if that requires drastically downscaled input, there should be high level configuration options for this (slowmo_video_instance_set_profile ([SPEED || ACCURACY]))

@valgit sure, as you can see in https://github.com/MathieuDuponchelle/gst-plugins-base/blob/slowmotion/gst/slowmo/interpolator_sV.cpp , I pass "left" and "right" buffers there, which I then construct "flows" from. Afaict , flows are an implementation detail that might be better to left hidden, and the API could let me simply provide timestamped "reference frames", and, depending on the defined configuration, interpolate the required amount of "fill frames", which I'd retrieve in the callback I provided.

These are just random thoughts though, maybe providing a lower level API akin to the the one I'm using in that port would be better, but if a higher-level API can be provided that would allow fully exploiting the features of the library I guess that would be better, my main concern here being that the notion of "control flow" might be something you don't want to expose if you can afford not to, as users like me will not want to learn such implementation "details".

commit_comments.body:
Hi there. 
Arch user here, and installing slowmovideo from git. 
I do believe that this commit broke the install paths of slowmoUI and slomoFlowEdit. 

They now end up in /usr/, rather than /usr/bin/

Can you confirm that this was intentional?

## I get an error when I install:

Install the project...
-- Install configuration: "Debug"
-- Installing: /data/aur/slowmovideo-git/pkg/slowmovideo-git/usr/bin/slowmoInterpolate
-- Installing: /data/aur/slowmovideo-git/pkg/slowmovideo-git/usr/bin/slowmoVideoInfo
-- Installing: /data/aur/slowmovideo-git/pkg/slowmovideo-git/usr/share/icons/AppIcon.png
-- Installing: /data/aur/slowmovideo-git/pkg/slowmovideo-git/usr/share/applications/slowmoUI.desktop
-- Installing: /data/aur/slowmovideo-git/pkg/slowmovideo-git/usr/bin/slowmoUI
-- fixup_qt5_executable
--   executable='/data/aur/slowmovideo-git/pkg/slowmovideo-git/usr/slowmoUI'
--   qtplugins=''
--   libs=''
--   dirs=''
--   plugins_dir=''
--   request_qt_conf=''
-- fixup_bundle
--   app='/data/aur/slowmovideo-git/pkg/slowmovideo-git/usr/slowmoUI'
--   libs=''
--   dirs=''
-- warning: _NOT_ handled - directory/file does not exist...
CMake Error at /usr/share/cmake-3.2/Modules/BundleUtilities.cmake:851 (message):
  error: fixup_bundle: not a valid bundle
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /data/aur/slowmovideo-git/src/slowmoVideo/src/cmake/DeployQt5.cmake:199 (fixup_bundle)
  slowmoVideo/slowmoUI/cmake_install.cmake:62 (FIXUP_QT5_EXECUTABLE)
  cmake_install.cmake:41 (include)

Makefile:85: recipe for target 'install' failed
make: **\* [install] Error 1
==> ERROR: A failure occurred in package().
##     Aborting...

Also, what's with the debug install config?

It works on Arch now as well, without the patch.

Thanks for looking into this for me!
